title: South Africa’s tourism industry likely to collapse if new visa regulations remain in place
text:
South Africa’s tourism industry likely to collapse if new visa regulations remain in place Published on : Monday, August 3, 2015
The Western Cape Department of Economic Opportunities, Tourism and Agriculture says South Africa’s tourism industry could collapse if new visa regulations remain in place.
MEC Alan Winde briefed members of the provincial Standing Committee of Economic Opportunities, Tourism and Agriculture on the impact that the country’s new immigration laws have had on key sectors including education, fishing and oil and gas.
The National Development Plan (NDP) has identified tourism as one of the key sectors to reduce inequality and eliminate poverty.
Last year, it contributed around 10% to job creation and the country’s economy.
A study commissioned by the Tourism Business Council of South Africa has predicted that the country will lose R1.4 billion in direct tourism spend this year, as a result of the changed immigration regulations.
It believes that the stringent requirements will turn visitors away and in doing so, so they will lose hundreds of millions of rand in income and scores of jobs.
Western Cape Minister of Economic Opportunities and Tourism, Alan Winde, says his department is gravely concerned.
“One hotel group tells us they are 20,000 bed spaces down. Some of the language schools are being impacted where they are retrenching people. The oil and gas…are really suffering so many of them are halving in size or retrenching staff.”
Winde says the long term spin-offs from all of this could bring the tourism industry to its knees.
“Obviously from a brand point of view we are going to lose many, many tourists because it has become difficult to come here. More importantly it’s even more difficult to come here if you have children. The major brand impact over time is that we are going to be seen as not a family friendly destination, so don’t come and visit us if you have a family.”
The two areas of concern are the requirements for all children younger than 18 years to be in possession of an unabridged birth certificate when travelling in and out of the country.
The other requires tourists to now appear in person during visa application processes in order to obtain a biometric visa.
Dutch national, Hermam Klok, almost had to cancel his annual family holiday to Cape Town because he didn’t have an unabridged birth certificate for his four-year old son.
“We had a bit of difficulty when we entered the country. We wanted to get a visa from them. In previous years it wasn’t a problem, but now they said no you need a birth certificate. We couldn’t find both when we were at home in the Netherlands, but we had our marriage book which also the children are written into.”
Filipe Lobo from Mozambique says even though his family didn’t encounter problems, many would-be visitors have been dissuaded from coming to South Africa because of red-tape.
Government is considering reviewing the controversial new visa regulations.
